data.text: Contents
Identifying the need for an individualised care plan ...................................................... 5
Caring for Women with Individualised Care Plans in place ........................................... 6
Individualised care planning (women requesting care outside of recommended practice)/ MEHT-21007/1.0
Page  of
Introduction

The A-EQUIP model states that all midwives will be supported by the PMA to advocate for women, including those planning more complex care that may fall outside traditional pathways, recognising that women have a legal right to be informed about the benefits and risks of all available options and to weigh these up for themselves, supported by their midwife and obstetrician where required (NHS England, 2017).

The Standards of Proficiency for Midwives states that Midwives should be able to advocate for women when their decisions are outside of clinical guidance, in order to minimise risk and maintain relationships. In addition to this, understand and respect women's rights to decline consent, and demonstrate the ability to provide appropriate care and support in these circumstances (NMC, 2019).

The PMA team at Mid-Essex recognise that this can be a particularly challenging part of the midwife's role and aim to be accessible in supporting midwives to feel confident in supporting women who require complex individualised care planning and the facilitation of this care.
Scope
This guidance explains the formal process for individualised care planning for women who are requesting care outside of recommended practice. The aim of this guidance is help midwives:
Minimise risk
Maintain relationships
Advocate for women's choice
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies,  guidelines  and  SOPs,  are  evidence-based  and  developed in line  with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Professional Midwifery Advocacy team will assist the midwives, obstetricians and allied health professionals in implementing the SOP when forming individualised care plans.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
All staff are required to provide care in line with this SOP.
Identifying the need for an individualised care plan
Any woman planning care outside of recommended practice should have an individualised care plan which should be documented in the PMA template (See Appendix A).
This is particularly important for women who are considered to be experiencing a complex pregnancy and are choosing to birth within a low risk/midwife-led setting.
This is important for women who are declining aspects of routine midwifery care.
Every effort should be made to complete the care plan in plenty of time before the onset of labour.
The process for individualised care planning
Upon recognition of the woman's wishes the midwife should have a brief discussion with the woman exploring the reasons for her choice and detail the benefits Vs risks in the hand held record.
Copies of relevant patient information leaflets and trust guidelines should be provided. This can be via email or post following initial contact (See Appendix B for additional resources).

A consultant appointment should be offered to enable a multidisciplinary approach, and the obstetrician should further discuss the risks Vs benefits on an individual basis with the woman. In particularly sensitive or complex cases it may be appropriate to contact the named obstetrician prior to the appointment to discuss the woman's wishes, this could be via email.

The birth plan should then be submitted to the PMA mailbox for review (PMA@meht.nhs.uk). This mailbox is monitored every Tuesday and Thursday. In the event of a plan requiring urgent review, please contact any PMA on duty that day and your line manager (See Appendix C).

Once the plan has been reviewed, arrange a follow up appointment to discuss and finalise the birth plan in conjunction with the woman. There is no legal requirement for the birth plan to be signed by the woman. The woman should be reassured that she can change her mind and alter her plan at any time.
Upload a copy of the plan to Lorenzo & circulate the plan to the relevant team leaders for each clinical area and file a hard copy in the hand held record.
(Refer to appendix D for flow chart.)
Caring for women with individualised care plans in place

The purpose of a documented individualised care plan is to give the woman and the midwife an opportunity to have an evidence based discussion regarding the risks and benefits of any choices that do not follow recommended practice as stated in the Trust's guidelines. Addressing this during the antenatal period enables the woman to make informed decisions regarding her care in plenty of time before the labour starts. This also gives the midwife the opportunity to seek support, refer appropriately gather the up-to-date evidence and communicate within her team.

The individualised care plan is evidence that the benefits and risks of choices made outside of recommended practice have been discussed, and the woman's wishes have been listened to. It will also evidence that measures to maintain safety have been considered and/or negotiated. It is not a legal document.

When caring for women in labour the individualised care plan does not replace evidence based discussions, but can act as a tool to ensure the woman is listened to and approached sensitively when in established labour.

In cases where women with complex pregnancies have chosen to birth in low risk/ midwife-led care settings against advice, the Senior Midwife on the labour ward should be informed at the onset of labour. The Senior Midwife should inform the on call Obstetrician (This can be added to the white Board on Labour Ward, there are 2 Obstetric consultant ward rounds occurring per day). The care plan can then be accessed remotely via Lorenzo if required.

In cases where women with complex pregnancies have chosen to birth in low risk/ midwife-led care settings against advice it may be necessary for two midwives to be present from the onset of labour. The decision for this must be included when forming the birth plan following discussion with Midwifery managers.

In instances where high risk infants are planned to be born in low risk care settings due to maternal choice, the on call neonatologist should be informed to discuss ongoing care planning and assessment.

In instances where high risk infants are born in low risk care settings due maternal choice, parental choice and consent must be respected regarding ongoing care following evidence based discussion with input from the relevant specialist.
Women should be reassured that they can change their plan at any time and that they will be supported with this and the birth plan will be adjusted accordingly.
Minimising risk

A multidisciplinary approach should be taken to individualised care planning and relevant specialist and obstetric/neonatologist advice/review should be sought on an individual basis and a Neonatal Alert form should be completed for high risk infants. In urgent cases this should be emailed directly to Dr Hassan for advice: Ahmed.Hassan@meht.nhs.uk (See Appendix E). and also speak to the on-call  Paediatrician at the time of referral.

data.url: MEHT-21007 Individualised care planning for women in maternity services 1.0.003.png

data.text: The reasons for women's choices should be sensitively discussed. Solutions and alternatives should be explored and steps taken in conjunction with the woman to minimise risk wherever possible.

In particularly complex cases the PMA team will escalate on an individual basis to the lead Midwife for Clinical Governance and if necessary the Consultants meeting, Head of Midwifery and Clinical Director.
Maintaining relationships
Every effort should be made in maintaining a positive and supportive relationship with the woman and her family.

Communication and relationship building are integral to providing safe and effective midwifery care in labour. The importance of this should be explored in situations where women do not wish to engage in basic communication with the midwife during labour care and issues surrounding consent should be discussed.
Advocating for woman's choice

It is the midwife's role to advocate for all women, including those planning more complex care that may fall outside traditional pathways, recognising that women have a legal right to be informed about the benefits and risks of all available options and to weigh these up for themselves, supported by their midwife and obstetrician where required (NHS England, 2017).

Midwives should recognise that women's perception of benefit and risk is subjective and may differ from that of the health care professional, but nonetheless needs to be respected and advocated for, as long as the woman has been given all of the information required to make an informed choice (NHS England, 2017).
Audit and monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy, the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the MSE Risk and Compliance Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local research guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix F)
References
NHS England. (2017). A-EQUIP: a model of clinical midwifery supervision. Retrieved from: https://www.england.nhs.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/a-equip-midwifery- supervision-model.pdf
The Nursing and Midwifery Council. (2018). The Code: Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses, midwives and nursing associates. London: The Nursing and Midwifery Council.
Appendix A
PMA individualised care planning template:
Name Hosp No NHS No Date of Birth
Individualised plan of care
Date: Midwife:
EDD:
Brief summary of reasons for birth plan.
Birth Plan
Medical history: Obstetric history: This pregnancy:
………..has been given the opportunity to read this plan and contact me if she wishes for any amendments.
Name
Position
Plan circulated to PMA team, team leader, copy uploaded to Lorenzo and patient records.
PMA individualised care planning template with prompts:
Name: Hosp No: NHS NoIndividualised plan of care Date: Midwife: Ensure you document who you are
EDD:
Start with a brief summary of reasons for the birth plan, perhaps include why the mother has made the decision to not follow recommendation.
Birth Plan
Include history like you would in an SBAR.
Medical history:
Include BMI & any physiological health or complex social factors
Obstetric history:
Include place of birth, EBL, Birth weight etc.
This pregnancy:
Include admissions, blood results, scan results
Include brief overview of what the consultant or other relevant specialist has advised.

table_items.text: Useful to break down this into separate blocks e.g Place of birth Birth Pool Examinations Fetal surveillance

Ensure you document the adverse outcomes or complications that could arise e.g not just ‘PPH'. What is a PPH? What is the treatment for a PPH? What are the potential outcomes if this occurs? Where is the safest place to manage a PPH & why?

Can you come to a compromise or take actions to make the situation safer? e.g If the mother is birthing at home against recommendation , would she consider the birthing unit? Is there anything we can offer to make the recommended place of
Clearly document why the mother is making these decisions, advocate for her.
Would the mother accept conservative measures? e.g active management of 3rd stage where there is a PPH risk, bloods on admission, venflon, exit pool for birth?

data.text: Appendix C PMA Team

In the absence of an allocated PMA you can contact any other PMA on duty or your line manager for urgent guidance and support. There is an allocated PMA for the day Tuesdays and Thursdays and the PMA mail box will be checked on these days PMA@meht.nhs.uk.

What are you proposing to change?
Created to give guidance to staff caring for women outside of the recommended guidelines.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

This guidance explains the formal process for individualised care planning for women who are requesting care outside of recommended practice. The aim of this guidance is help midwives advocate for women and support their choices.
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
